entry.title: Re: Changing Service Entry Sheet - Call Transaction / BAPI / etc
entry.content:
Official answer by SAP in the SAP note 1977305 - Is there a BAPI to modify Service Entry Sheets? - SAP for Me:

"There is no BAPI to change or modify (apart from delete, release, etc.) a service entry sheet. Please consider using the workaround below:

  • Delete the old SES by BAPI_ENTRYSHEET_DELETE.
  • Create a new SES based on the new information by BAPI_ENTRYSHEET_CREATE."

entry.title: Re: Issue with Batch-Specific UOM Quantity Display in War...
entry.content:
Hello @SNarayan 

Thank you for your question and for sharing the screenshots. This is standard behaviour in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

  • Inventory Stock apps, like Stock ‚Äì Single Material, display stock in the base UoM (TO) along with batch conversion details, making it easier to understand and manage your stock.
  • Warehouse Monitor displays stock in the alternative or batch-specific units of measure (EA) based on batch characteristics.

Not an error, just a different display logic, Inventory vs. EWM. Use stock reports if both views are necessary.

With kind regards

Chuma

SAP Help-Batch-Specific Units of Measure

SAP Help - Warehouse Management Monitor

entry.title: Re: SAP Authorization issue
entry.content:
So, basically you want to limit the activity for the user and I assume you are working with Fiori. 

Create a custom BR, assign the following catalogs according to your needs: 

SAP_MM_BC_INV_DOC_DSP_PC - for display

SAP_MM_BC_INV_PARK_PC - hold/park/park as complete

SAP_MM_BC_INV_RELEASE_PC - release 

Also you need to check the backend authorizations, according to the note 2931137 - User authorizations in Supplier Invoice Apps (On Premise) - SAP S/4HANA

Find the roles on user with the respective auth. objects, only assign roles without activity 01 (create)

note: When you are raising questions, It's better to elaborate the product and function you are working on. private cloud? on premise? public cloud... fiori or gui?

entry.title: Unpacking the new SAP Business Suite
entry.content:
This blog intends to provide a quick explanation of the newly announced SAP Business Suite. The blog contains the latest information as of August 2025.

In February 2025, SAP announced the new SAP Business Suite (https://www.sap.com/events/business-unleashed.html), which was also covered in detail at our prime SAP SAPPHIRE events in Orlando, Madrid, and all the SAP Now events around the world. But you might be wondering what the new SAP Business Suite is.

Simply put, the SAP Business Suite helps our customers drive business innovation to achieve more valuable business outcomes in a constantly changing economy‚Äîby uniting core SAP business applications, data, and Business AI capabilities.

New SAP Business Suite

The SAP Business Suite is not simply a harmonization of release and maintenance schedules for SAP‚Äôs portfolio of solutions. It serves as a transformation engine, helping customers generate rapid cycles of innovation and continuous improvement as a service. This enables organizations to deliver greater business value and achieve improved outcomes through end-to-end processes.

SAP‚Äôs Business Suite applications (like SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP SuccessFactors, SAP Concur, etc.) and SAP Business Technology Platform aren‚Äôt just siloed applications; they are integrated along end to end business process, supporting you in every business decision and outcome. This integration ensures that every action taken within these applications generates trusted, business-critical data at its source.

Within the SAP Business Suite, we have also integrated the SAP Business Data Cloud. The SAP Business Data Cloud was also announced in February 2025 . The SAP Business Data Cloud centralizes, harmonizes, and enriches the data produced by the SAP applications and non-SAP applications. So the SAP Business Data Cloud helps us unify data into a single source of truth. Now if this data is contextualized, reliable, and accessible, this data becomes the fuel for advanced AI-driven insights. SAP Business AI, included in the SAP Business Suite, goes beyond basic automation. Through SAP Joule, our AI copilot and the embedded AI capabilities in our applications, employees can orchestrate intelligent agents to collaborate across functions or get enhanced scenarios to increase productivity. This strategy breaks down silos, driving real-time, cross-enterprise optimization. We know our customers are deploying AI in isolated projects, but with our SAP Business Suite strategy, we weave it throughout your organization, unlocking value and resilience at scale.

Let‚Äôs get practical and explain how our customers consume the SAP Business Suite as a service. Next, I will cover the new SAP Business Suite Packages and the journey our customers can follow to implement them.

SAP has created buying center-based packages which provide our customers with defined functional capabilities within our core applications portfolio, data, and Business AI.  The idea is that the package can provide all the necessary capabilities for this buying center and its teams to carry out their responsibilities.

New buying center-based SAP Business Suite Packages

Now, SAP is providing two journeys for our customers so they can consume the SAP Business Suite as a service. The journeys are RISE with SAP and GROW with SAP. Before the February 2025 announcement, RISE with SAP was focused on our SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, and GROW with SAP was focused on our SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

Customer Journeys to New SAP Business Suite

Following the introduction of the SAP Business Suite, we have evolved our programs and made several enhancements to the commercial packages supporting these journeys to better serve our customers.

RISE with SAP is a journey focused on existing SAP ERP on-premise customers who are looking to modernize their legacy systems with SAP Business Suite, while GROW with SAP is a journey focused on new SAP ERP customers looking to start fresh with SAP Business Suite.

We also made changes to some names to group our solutions. We now refer to everything relevant to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and its extended capabilities offered in the SAP Business Suite Packages as "SAP Cloud ERP," and everything relevant to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and the extended capabilities offered in the SAP Business Suite Packages as "SAP Cloud ERP Private."

Now, how do we align the SAP Business Suite packages with the customer journeys?  In the figure, you can see that customers have options depending on their SAP journey and buying center. These packages can also be consumed by buying center or brought together for the entire company and buying centers. If you would like to learn more about our packages and what is included, I suggest you visit this link: https://www.sap.com/products/business-suite/pricing.html

Buying center-based packages that enable customer journeys to the new SAP Business Suite

In this blog, I want to focus more on the journeys and packages that have traditionally covered ERP functionalities by highlighting the CIO buying center and the needs of a company-wide system, including other C-suite buying centers who rely on ERP as a comprehensive solution to streamline the introduction of this concept. I won‚Äôt cover other subscriptions like add-ons, data product packages, and AI packages included in the SAP Business Suite, etc., to keep it simple and easy to understand.

Let's begin with Cloud ERP Private. This package is designed to provide customers with tailored-to-fit functionality, a very flexible system in which they maintain the governance of the system while SAP supports operations.

Here, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition is included; however, this package encompasses many more capabilities and components compared to traditional ERP (SAP ERP 6.0). The following components are included:

Components included in Cloud ERP Private Package

The SAP Finance and SAP Supply Chain Management packages include many different SAP components supporting the CFO and COO buying centers in running their business responsibilities. Here is where you find SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, a system designed to drive business standardization using a fit-to-standard approach, with rapid and agile innovation cycles, operated and governed by SAP.

Each of these packages includes two types of sub-packages: Base and Premium. The idea is to provide customers with flexibility when deciding on the main capabilities for each buying center. Below, I present the capabilities of the two packages:

Components included in SAP Finance Package

Components included in SAP Supply Chain Package

As you can see from the packages, the entitlements provided encompass more comprehensive capabilities and components compared to the standalone SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, offering greater business benefits and functional features.

To view the current packages and included capabilities, please refer to: https://www.sap.com/products/business-suite/pricing.html

Sample Customer Journeys:

SAP ERP 6.0 customer looking to move to the new SAP Business Suite.

This customer will use the RISE with SAP customer journey to move to the new SAP Business Suite. Here, the customer will have the option to select between various packages depending on their business needs. Considering that this customer runs full capabilities (FI-CO, SD, MM, PP, QM, etc.) in SAP ERP 6.0, below are the choices:

Customer Journey ‚Äì RISE with SAP ‚Äì Final Destination SAP Business Suite

SAP will support the customer with the selection of the right packages by using the SAP Digital Discovery Assessment (SAP DDA). The SAP DDA helps the customer assess functional needs and provides recommendations accordingly. However, it is important to note that the packages are meant to serve two distinct business purposes: Cloud ERP Private‚Äîtailored-to-fit functionality with a highly flexible system where the customer maintains governance while SAP supports operations‚Äîand SAP Finance & SAP Supply Chain, which is designed to drive business standardization using a fit-to-standard approach, featuring rapid and agile innovation cycles, and operated and governed by SAP.  While the SAP DDA assesses functional requirements, the customer must decide on their main strategy: whether to implement and operate their systems with a tailored-to-fit solution or embrace a fit-to-standard model.

SAP Digital Discovery Assessment

Now let's talk a bit more in detail about the journey based on the package selection.

Cloud ERP Private ‚Äì An SAP ERP 6.0 customer needs tailored-to-fit functionality, with a very flexible system in which they maintain governance of the system while SAP supports operations. This customer has selected the Cloud ERP Private Package. Here, they first need to plan their journey to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition from SAP ERP 6.0 using one of the known transition paths: New Implementation, Selective Data Transition, or System Conversion. They will benefit from the use of transformation tools and services included in the package and can also take advantage of the other components included in the package.

Customer Journey ‚Äì RISE with SAP ‚Äì Final Destination SAP Business Suite via Cloud ERP Private Package

SAP Finance and SAP Supply Chain Management packages ‚Äì An SAP ERP 6.0 customer decided on a state-of-the-art system designed to drive business standardization using a fit-to-standard approach, with rapid and agile innovation cycles and operated and governed by SAP. This customer has selected the SAP Finance and SAP Supply Chain Management packages. Here, they first need to plan their journey to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition from SAP ERP 6.0 using a New Implementation. They will benefit from using SAP Activate, the SAP Signavio Process Navigator, and SAP Cloud ALM to drive their implementation, and can also take advantage of the other components included in the package (either base or premium).

Customer Journey ‚Äì RISE with SAP ‚Äì Final Destination SAP Business Suite via SAP Finance and SAP Supply Chain Packages

To make the most of all the components included in these packages, the SAP Activate Methodology has been enhanced, and there is now a new roadmap available for provisioning SAP Business Suite Packages. I highly recommend using it to take full advantage of the additional components offered.

New SAP Activate for provisioning new SAP Business Suite Packages

New SAP customer looking to move to the new SAP Business Suite.

This customer will use the GROW with SAP customer journey to move to the new SAP Business Suite. Here, the customer will be defaulted to the SAP Finance and SAP Supply Chain packages, as our SAP Cloud ERP is the most transformational one.

However, if the new customer might be looking for more tailored-to-fit functionality‚Äîa very flexible system in which they maintain the governance of the system while SAP supports operations‚Äîthe Cloud ERP Package can be offered after the review with the SAP Digital Discovery Assessment.

Customer Journey ‚Äì GROW with SAP ‚Äì Final Destination SAP Business Suite via SAP Finance and SAP Supply Chain Packages

As indicated before to make the most of all the components included in these SAP Finance and SAP Supply Chain Management packages, the SAP Activate Methodology has been enhanced, and there is now a new roadmap available for provisioning SAP Business Suite Packages.

 

So, what about the other SAP Business Suite packages‚ÄîSAP Strategic Procurement, SAP Core HR, and SAP CX?

These packages were designed based on personas. They provide our customers with defined functional capabilities within our core applications portfolio, data, and Business AI for a specific line of business. However, in combination with the Cloud ERP Private Package or the SAP Finance & SAP Supply Chain Management Package, they can offer even greater business benefits.

So, as in the example above, if an SAP ERP 6.0 customer is also running a legacy SAP ERP HCM system, they can adopt the new package for SAP Core HR to run SAP SuccessFactors and help them manage strategic human resources with solutions like SuccessFactors Employee Central, SuccessFactors Employee Central Payroll, SuccessFactors Time Tracking, etc. SAP SuccessFactors is the next-generation cloud HR product, and this is where we are recommending our customers to move.

If the SAP ERP 6.0 customer is running a legacy SAP SRM 7.0 or any other legacy system to manage strategic sourcing, contract management, or is looking to implement these capabilities, they can choose SAP Strategic Procurement‚Äîan integrated solution bundle for managing the source-to-contract process through sourcing, contract management, supplier lifecycle, and performance management. Included solutions are: SAP Ariba Sourcing, SAP Ariba Contracts, SAP Ariba Supplier Lifecycle and Performance.

If the SAP ERP 6.0 customer is running a legacy SAP CRM 7.0 or any other legacy system to manage comprehensive sales management, service management, or marketing capabilities, then the SAP CX Package (to be delivered in Q3 2025) can help the customer leverage the latest CX portfolio, such as SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud.

All Business Suite Packages that are available to existing on-premises SAP ERP 6.0 customers through the RISE with SAP customer journey

The same availability of SAP Business Suite Packages can be provided to a new SAP customer to complement the SAP Finance and SAP Supply Chain Management Packages.

All Business Suite Packages that are available to new SAP customers through the GROW with SAP customer journey

As indicated before, the new SAP Business Suite is not just a harmonization of a release and maintenance schedule of SAP‚Äôs portfolio of solutions. It‚Äôs a transformation engine that helps customers create rapid cycles of innovation end-to-end and continuous improvement as a service. In this regard, SAP is planning to make running the SAP Business Suite easier for customers and is planning to manage the integration of components. Early next year, SAP plans to begin offering SAP Cloud ERP + SAP Core HR managed integration as a service and will continue to introduce more in the future. Of course, these plans are subject to change.

We believe the new SAP Business Suite will help our customers gain more business outcomes by unlocking value and resilience at scale by combining core applications, data and business AI.

I would like to thank my colleagues, Daniel Kesenheimer, Elena Tewari, Matt Emmert & Marcus Venth, for their review and feedback on this blog.

Your insights and opinions are valuable, so please don't hesitate to contribute by commenting on this blog.

entry.title: Could not fetch JWT bearer token for service of type destination. Unable to map issuer: Origin claim
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I have two CAP applications, where I'm doing the backend services. The apps are in the same subaccount, and it have individual xsuaa services.

The application "A" exposed a service url to be consumed by UI5 application with a destination type OAuth2UserTokenExchange and it's working fine.

The application "B" exposed other service using other destination with the same type OAuth2UserTokenExchange. In this service, I need consume the service from "A". To do this, I imported it as external service and I configured the destination in the package.json file.

When I consume it, using cds objects ( const remoteService = await cds.connect.to('API...'), I get this error:

ERR message: 'Error during request to remote service: Failed to load destination. Caused by: Could not fetch JWT bearer token for service of type destination: HTTP response from https://xxx/oauth/token was 401: {"error":"unauthorized","error_description":"Unable to map issuer: Origin claim is missing in the token."}.'

If I use a destination type OAuth2ClientCredentials works correctly.

Is it possible to propagate the user token using the CDS object, or do I need to make a REST call that includes the token?"

Thanks and regards.

entry.title: Re: BAPI to unaccept service entry sheet
entry.content:
No that's wrong. The question is about revoking the acceptance, not about undo release.

In transaction ML81N, that's the undo button:

The only way is to use Batch Input. It works on ML81N:

" Batch input to revoke acceptance of service entry sheet
" based on ZCL_TOOL_BI_TRANSACTION:
"   Blog: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blogs-by-members/community-project-batch-input-toolbox-for-abap/ba-p/14068601
"   Code: https://github.com/jrgkraus/tool-bi
FORM revoke_acceptance_of_ses USING iv_entrysheet TYPE bapiessr-sheet_no.
  DATA(lo_ml81n) = NEW zcl_tool_bi_transaction( 'ML81N' ).

  " 1st screen of ML81N: click on the Other command button
  lo_ml81n->new_dynpro(
    )->program( 'SAPLMLSR'
    )->dynpro( '0400'
    )->ok_code( '=SELP' ).

  " Popup asking which service sheet to display
  lo_ml81n->new_dynpro(
    )->program( 'SAPLMLSR'
    )->dynpro( '0340'
    )->field( 'RM11R-LBLNI' )->value( iv_entrysheet
    )->ok_code( '=ENTE' ).

  " Screen showing the service sheet in display mode, click on the Edit button
  lo_ml81n->new_dynpro(
    )->program( 'SAPLMLSR'
    )->dynpro( '0400'
    )->ok_code( '=AKCH' ).

  " Screen showing the service sheet in modification mode, click on the Revoke Acceptance button
  " NB: potential errors:
  "   - If the sheet is not accepted (ESSR-KZABN = ''), the Revoke Acceptance button is not shown: The function code cannot be selected (Message No. 00255)
  lo_ml81n->new_dynpro(
    )->program( 'SAPLMLSR'
    )->dynpro( '0400'
    )->ok_code( '=ACCR' ).

  " Screen showing the service sheet in modification mode, click on the Save button
  lo_ml81n->new_dynpro(
    )->program( 'SAPLMLSR'
    )->dynpro( '0400'
    )->ok_code( '=SAVE' ).

  " Popup asking for document date and accounting date
  DATA lv_aujourdhui_format_externe TYPE c LENGTH 10.
  lv_aujourdhui_format_externe = |{ sy-datum DATE = USER }|.
  lo_ml81n->new_dynpro(
    )->program( 'SAPLMLSR'
    )->dynpro( '0110'
    )->field( 'IMKPF-BLDAT' )->value( lv_aujourdhui_format_externe
    )->field( 'IMKPF-BUDAT' )->value( lv_aujourdhui_format_externe
    )->ok_code( 'ENTE' ).

  DATA lv_mode                    TYPE ctu_params-dismode VALUE 'N'.
  DATA lo_logger                  TYPE REF TO zif_logger.
  DATA lv_result_call_transaction TYPE sysubrc.

  lo_logger = zcl_logger_factory=>create_log( ).
  lo_ml81n->mode( lv_mode )->update( 'L' ).

  lv_result_call_transaction = lo_ml81n->run( lo_logger ).

  IF lv_resultat_call_transaction <> 0.
    " < 1000 : error message (A or E) during batch input execution,
    " = 1001 : technical error (messages S00341 to S00349)
    lo_logger->popup( ).
  ENDIF.
ENDFORM.

entry.title: Re: How to send Data (Integration) from SAP Datasphere to...
entry.content:
Hi @897654208074 

For your scenario integrating SAP Datasphere with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud the integration is supported but requires correct communication management setup on the S/4HANA Cloud side. Let me break it down for you:

Below are the integration Approach

  • Group Reporting Data Collection consumes data via OData services from external sources, in this case SAP Datasphere.
  • Datasphere acts as the source system, while S/4HANA Cloud GRDC is the target.
  • Communication between the two is secured by creating a Communication System, Communication User and Communication Arrangement in S/4HANA Cloud.

 

Here are steps you need to configure

  1. In S/4HANA Public Cloud
  1. First, create a Communication User
    • App: Maintain Communication Users
    • Define user ID and password which will be used by Datasphere.
  2. Secondly, create a Communication System
    • App: Maintain Communication Systems
    • Enter the following:
      • Host = Datasphere tenant URL for example https://<tenant>.eu10.hcs.cloud.sap
      • Outbound authentication = User ID and password of the communication user.
      • Inbound: assign the same communication user.
  3. Create a Communication Arrangement
    • App: Maintain Communication Arrangements
    • Scenario: SAP_COM_0108 Group Reporting Data Collection
    • Assign the Communication System and User.
    • This generates the service URL and credentials that Datasphere will use to push data.

 

  1. In SAP Datasphere
  • Use the Data Flow or Data Integration feature to push data into the GRDC OData service:
    • Endpoint is URL from the Communication Arrangement in S/4HANA Cloud.
    • Authentication is Communication User and password created above.
  • Datasphere allows you to map your data consolidation unit, FS item, partner unit, etc. to the GRDC input structure.

 

Yes, all communication is done over HTTPS, so data in transit is encrypted. The Communication Arrangement enforces secure authentication.

SAP Group Reporting Data Collection

SAP Group Reporting Data Collection with SAP S/4HANA Cloud

Integration with SAP Datasphere

I hope this provides the necessary details. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I'm trying to set up change pointers on planned orders (LOIPLO) to track changes, but I'm running into an issue and hope someone can point me in the right direction.

I've already completed the following configuration steps:

  • SCDO - Created change document object for LOIPLO

  • BD50 - Activated change pointers for LOIPLO

  • BD52 - Defined fields for which change documents should be written

The general change pointers are activated in BD61 and work perfectly fine with other message types, so the basic configuration seems to be correct.

However, when I modify the Total Quantity field in a planned order, no new entry is created in table BDCP2. This is quite puzzling since everything else appears to be working as expected.

Have I overlooked an important configuration step? I'm grateful for any hints or suggestions from anyone who has worked with LOIPLO change pointers before.

Thanks in advance for your help!

entry.title: Designing Value Help Services for the Situation Handling - Extended Framework
entry.content:
Understanding Value Help Services: What They Are and Why They Matter?

Value help services are a cornerstone feature in enhancing user experience by offering context-specific assistance. These services provide users with relevant suggestions and options based on the current situation, making tasks more intuitive and efficient. But what exactly are value help services, and how do they help users? Let's dive into their key functions and benefits.

Key Functions and Benefits of Value Help Services

  • Easing Data Entry
    One of the primary goals of value help services is to simplify data entry. For instance, when inputting data like product lists or options that require predefined choices, these services provide a seamless way to select the appropriate data. This reduces the risk of errors and speeds up the data input process.
  • Use in Situation Handling
    Value help services are particularly useful when it comes to defining condition filters for situation templates and types in the Manage Situation Types - Extended app, as well as in the My Situations ‚Äì Extended app as part of the filter bar. By offering context-specific suggestions, they help users navigate and interact with the system more efficiently, turning complex tasks into manageable ones.

Let's take a closer look at how these services work with an example. Figure 1 below shows how you can choose a plane type when defining a condition filter in the Manage Situation Types ‚Äì Extended app. Value help services ensure that when you don't have to manually input each plane type; instead, you can select from a list of predefined options. You also see additional information, such as the total seats of the plane, that help you choose the appropriate plane type.

Throughout this blog, we'll continue to use the plane type value help as an example to illustrate how value help services enhance user experience and streamline processes.


Figure 1: Value Help for Plane Type in Condition Filter dialog in the Manage Situation Types - Extended app 

Designing an OData-Based Value Help Service

In this section, we explore the design of an OData-based value help service, breaking down its key components and steps. This will serve as a foundation for integrating these services into the extended framework for Situation Handling. We‚Äôll use artifacts from the Flight situation object (ID: SITDEMO_FLIGHT), which is included as a demo object in the extended framework. The main components and their relations are shown in Figure 2 below:


Figure 2: Overview on Artifacts for the Value Help Definition

Key Components of an OData-Based Value Help

  • CDS Views
    • Value Help Source CDS View: Define the source entity that serves as the primary data source for the value help service. This view and its view entities are referenced from the situation object.
    • Value Help Provider CDS View(s): Design one or more CDS views specifically for the value help, which may include additional filters or joins to meet the value help requirements.
      Both the base CDS view as well as the Value Help Provider Views contain annotations that are essential for enhancing the functionality and user experience of value helps.
  • OData Service
    Naturally, OData-based value helps must be exposed as OData services to be accessible to SAP Fiori applications including their respective Service Definition and Business Service.
  • Situation Object
    Linking the source CDS view in a situation object in the Manage Situation Objects app.

Steps to Design an OData-Based Value Help Service

1. Define the Value Help Source CDS View

Start by creating the source CDS view, which will serve as the primary data source for your value help. This view should include all relevant fields that users might need for filtering or searching. Below is an example based on the Sitn2DemoFlightVH view provided by SAP:

@ObjectModel.viewType: #CONSUMPTION
@ObjectModel.dataCategory: #VALUE_HELP
define view entity C_Sitn2DemoFlightVH as select from R_Sitn2DemoFlight {
  @Consumption.valueHelpDefinition:[{entity: {name: 'C_Sitn2DemoPlaneVH', element: 'SitnDemoPlaneType'}}]  
      key cast( '' as sit2_demo_plane_type ) as SitnDemoPlaneType
}

This view only serves to reference the value helps for the entity sets it contains ‚Äì it is not necessary to actually retrieve all field values here, i.e., as shown in the above entity set, it is possible to simply hard-code the field value as ''. The important annotations in this view are the @Consumption.valueHelpDefinition annotations which define the Value Help Provider View (entity.name) and the element (entity.element) in the target entity that is linked to the respective fields (SitnDemoPlaneVH and SitnDemoPlaneType in the example above). For more details, check out the Consumption Annotations page in SAP Help Portal.

2. Create the Value Help Provider View

Next, create a CDS view specifically for the value help.[1] This view may include filters, joins, or additional fields necessary for the value help functionality.

@ObjectModel.viewType: #CONSUMPTION
@ObjectModel.dataCategory: #VALUE_HELP
@ObjectModel.representativeKey: 'SitnDemoPlaneType'
define view entity C_Sitn2DemoPlaneVH as select from R_Sitn2DemoPlane
{
@Search.defaultSearchElement: true
@Search.ranking: #HIGH
key SitnDemoPlaneType,

@Search.defaultSearchElement: true 
@Search.ranking: #LOW
SitnDemoSeatsMaxQty,
... 
}

Besides the SitnDemoPlaneType, that was referenced by the entity.element in the Source CDS View above and must be part of the Value Help Provider View, the view incorporates extra fields like the number of seats available. To enhance user experience, the view can also include optional search annotations.

3. Expose as OData Service

Finally, expose the value help CDS view as an OData service to make it accessible to SAP Fiori applications and other systems consuming OData services. Currently, only OData V2 services are supported that needs to be implemented by using Business Service. Ensure the Service Definition includes the Source CDS View and all referenced Value Help Provider Views, like in the example below:

@EndUserText.label: 'Value help for Situation Demo'
define service C_SITN2DEMOFLIGHTVHSRV {
expose C_Sitn2DemoFlightVH as FlightVH;
expose C_Sitn2DemoPlaneVH as PlaneVH;
}

This service definition is afterwards used for the service binding. Please use ‚ÄúOData V2 ‚Äì UI‚Äù as binding type. The result should look like the service binding below:[2]


Figure 3: Service Binding for Value Help Service

Extending a Situation Object with a Value Help

We'll now guide you through the steps to add a value help service in the Manage Situation Objects app. To do so, open your situation object in the Manage Situation Objects app. We are again using the Flight situation object (ID: SITDEMO_FLIGHT) that comes with the extended framework, but with a different service that got exposed using Business Services.

Add a Value Help Service in the Manage Situation Objects App

  1. Create a New Value Help Service
    To add a new value help service, you'll start by clicking the "Create" button in your situation object in the Manage Situation Objects app.
  2. Configure the Value Help Service
    in the Value Help Services section, fill the following fields with the specified values:
    1. Service Protocol Version: Set this to V2.
    2. Service Path: Choose Standard - there are currently no other options available.
    3. Service Binding: Enter the name of the service binding of the value help service you‚Äôve created. In the example shown in Figure 3, this is C_SITN2DEMOFLIGHTVHV2.
    4. Service Version: Use the latest service version from your service binding.In the example shown in Figure 3, this version is 1.
  3. Add Properties.
    Add the entity set of the Source CDS View here, not any of the Value Help Provider Views that are also included in the service. Please note that you have to use the name of the entity set as defined in the Service Definition, not the name of the CDS view, i.e. for our example use FlightVH and not C_Sitn2DemoFlightVH. Add the name of the property that you want to use.

The results should look like the figure below:


Figure 4: Manage Situation Objects: add a Value Help Service

Mapping Value Help Entities in the Situation Object Structures

To complete your value help setup, you provide a mapping between the fields of the CDS views you use in the structure of your situation object and the properties in the value help service entities. We'll walk you through the necessary steps to do this below:

  1. Open the Structure in the Manage Situation Objects app
    Navigate to the structure within your situation object that you wish to extend with value help functionality.
  2. Access the Value Help Mapping Section
    Next, go to the "Value Help Mapping" section. This is where you will map the fields to the value help entities.
  3. Create a New Mapping
    1. Click on the "Create" button to add a new value help mapping.
    2. Select a Field: Choose the field from the structure that you want to enhance with a value help. For our example, we're using SITNDEMOPLANETYPE.
    3. Assign the Value Help
      After selecting the field, use the value help to select the value help ID you modeled in the previous steps. Ensure you match the entity set and property correctly. For our example, the mapping should be:
      Value Help ID: VALUE_HELP_DEMO
      Entity Set: FlightVH
      Property: SitnDemoPlaneType

The results should look like the figure below:


Figure 5: Manage Situation Objects: mapping of Value Help Service and Structure fields

By following these steps, you'll successfully add the value help service to your situation object, enhancing your ability to manage situations effectively.

Using the Situation Object Enhanced with Value Help Services

Once you've created your situation objects and enhanced them with value help services, they're ready for use in situation scenarios, situation templates, and situation types. Most of your defined content is automatically propagated, making changes‚Äîeven in value help services‚Äîimmediately active.

However, situation type updates are handled different due to performance caching. If you add value help services after creating a situation type, you'll need to refresh it by creating a new version of the situation type. You can do this by making a small change for example in the type description and saving afterwards. This will trigger the value help changes to become active. For any situation type you create after enhancing your situation objects, the changes will immediately be applied.

Tips and tricks for testing and in case of problems

Testing your value help service

To quickly test if your value help service works correctly, create a new situation template that makes use of the situation object[3] that you‚Äôve defined and check the condition filters. Make sure to select the correct trigger or anchor object for the condition filter to see all fields and their value helps.
An example for the Demo Scenario is shown in Figure 1 Value Help for Plane Type in Condition Filter dialog in the Manage Situation Types - Extended app.

Check the $metadata of your value help service

When the value helps are not working, please check the $metadata of your service. All fields with value help services should have the <Annotation Term="Common.ValueList"> property.

An example is the $metadata of the Demo Application

URL: ‚Ä¶/sap/opu/odata/sap/C_SITN2DEMOFLIGHTVH_CDS/$metadata 

<Annotation Term="Common.ValueList">
...
<Record>
<PropertyValue Property="CollectionPath" String="C_Sitn2DemoRegionVH" />
...
</Annotations>

Similar annotation should be available in the OData Service defined in the Service Binding. Simply extend the service URL with /$metadata and check the properties you annotated. There should be a Common.ValueList annotation for each field annotated with @Consumption.valueHelpDefinition in your Source CDS View.

Creating or Updating Situation Types after Situation Object Changes

As mentioned earlier (section ‚ÄúUsing the Value Help enhanced objects‚Äù) remember that situation objects are cached for performance reasons in situation types when the situation type is created. This means that changes in the situation object are not reflected for the existing situation types, even if you might see them already in the situation template, unless they are updated.
So, whenever an update of situation objects was required, please remember to change or create new situation types to reflect the changes.

Update structure mapping after changing Value Help Services

Whenever you update a value help service in a situation object, , make sure to also update the value help mapping in the respective structure of the situation object.
Figure 6 shows an example where the entity set is wrong (ZAS_VH_BASE_VIRE) and should be changed to the correct name of the entity set as it‚Äôs exposed in the service (-> FlightVH). Once this was changed in the Value Help section, it also needs to be changed in the Value Help Mapping in the Structure section(s).


Figure 6: Manage Situation Object: Reflect changes in Value Help also to the Structure Mapping.

Popup ‚ÄúNo authorization to access value help for <<FIELDNAME>> . Please define conditions‚Äù

While using the condition filter dialog, you might encounter the following error:
Figure 7: Popup ‚ÄúNo authorization to access value help for <<FIELDNAME>> . Please define conditions‚Äù

This error can arise from two primary issues:

  1. Value Help Service Authorization: There may be an authorization problem with the value help service, which needs to be addressed in the backend ‚Äì check the DCLs assigned to the views and the authorizations given to the user.
  2. Service Issues: The service itself might be experiencing problems.

Troubleshooting Steps:
To diagnose if the issue is with the service, use the browser‚Äôs network tab in the debugging tools to check for a /$metadata request related to your value help service.
Here‚Äôs what you might find:

  • Service Not Published: If the service URL is unavailable, it‚Äôs likely that the service hasn‚Äôt been published. Ensure that the service is properly published.
  • Wrong OData Version: If you see an error message similar to
<code>/IWFND/MED/170</code>
<message xml:lang="en">No service found for namespace '', name '...', version '0001'</message>
<innererror>‚Äã

it‚Äôs probable that the incorrect OData version was used. Ensure you are using ‚ÄúOData V2 ‚Äì UI‚Äù as specified in the ‚ÄúExpose as OData Service‚Äù step in the section ‚ÄúSteps to Design an OData-Based Value Help Service.‚Äù

By following these steps, you should be able to identify and resolve the underlying issue causing the error.

Conclusion

Modeling value help services for the extended framework for Situation Handling is a powerful way to enhance user experience by providing context-specific assistance. By following the principles and best practices demonstrated in the Flight Demo, experienced developers can create robust and effective value help services tailored to their projects.
Stay tuned for more advanced techniques and in-depth discussions as we continue to explore the capabilities of the extended framework for Situation Handling.
Happy coding!

Footnotes:

[1] Multiple Value Help Provider Views need to be created when the source CDS view references several Value Help Provider Views in the annotations.
[2]  Note -This service does not exist in the Flight situation object that uses a different mechanism. However, the target design is to use service bindings.
[3]  When creating the situation template, you first need to create a situation scenario where the situation object that is enhanced with value help services is used as trigger or anchor object. The value help becomes visible in the value help for the field it got assigned to in the condition‚Äôs filters of the trigger or anchor object.

entry.title: JDBC (Microsoft SQL) Connectivity issue In SAP CPI
entry.content:
Hello,

I'm trying to establish a connection to an on prem Microsoft SQL server via JDBC adapter in SAP CPI. I'm getting an error
org.springframework.jdbc.CannotGetJdbcConnectionException: Failed to obtain JDBC Connection; nested exception is com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.SQLServerException: The TCP/IP connection to the host localhost, port 1106 has failed. Error: "The driver received an unexpected pre-login response. Verify the connection properties and check that an instance of SQL Server is running on the host and accepting TCP/IP connections at the port. This driver can be used only with SQL Server 2005 or later.". ClientConnectionId:1fe33d15-3b89-41fa-b211-672cb643ff12, cause: com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.SQLServerException: The TCP/IP connection to the host localhost, port 1106 has failed. Error: "The driver received an unexpected pre-login response. Verify the connection properties and check that an instance of SQL Server is running on the host and accepting TCP/IP connections at the port. This driver can be used only with SQL Server 2005 or later.". ClientConnectionId:1fe33d15-3b89-41fa-b211-672cb643ff12
The driver I've installed in CPI is V8.4.1

My JDBC configuration is 

Is this the correct driver version I'm using, and in the error, it mentions port as 1106, I've not maintained that port, why is it coming in the error? How do I resolve this error?

Please help.

Thanks in advance!
Shreyas.

entry.title: Use of VBA macro "Workbook_BeforeSave" in SAP DM
entry.content:
Hi,

We have embedded a VBA macro in a module within an Excel file. This macro needs to run before the file is saved. Consequently, we inserted the following code into "ThisWorkbook":

Private Sub Workbook_BeforeSave(ByVal SaveAsUI As Boolean, Cancel As Boolean)

Call Primadichiudere 'Name of the macro

End Sub

When we use the file outside of SAP DM, everything works correctly. However, when we test the Excel file after uploading it to SAP DM, we have noticed the following:

  • If we run the macro manually (F5), it works and executes correctly.
  • If we save the file using the floppy disk icon (i.e., not in SAP DM), it works correctly.
  • If we try to save with "apply changes," the macro doesn't work. It doesn't give any error messages, so it's not a debug issue; it simply fails to do what it's supposed to do (e.g. it doesn't copy or paste values)

Is this normal, or are we doing something wrong? Is there a way to solve this issue?

Thank you very much,

Sofia

entry.title: From Movie Theater to Global Stage: How a "Gully Boy" Moment Changed Everything
entry.content:
In a darkened movie theater in Amsterdam, Nagesh Polu made a decision that would seem absurd to most people. Fifteen minutes into the film, he'd already guessed the ending (he is an avid movie goer, so this happens often). So, he did what any dedicated learner would do‚Äîhe pulled out his phone and started studying SAP SuccessFactors materials instead.

"That's probably the weirdest place I've ever studied," Nagesh laughs, "but it perfectly captures who I am. I can't waste a moment when there's something new to learn."

Nagesh's story begins in Chirala, India, where he earned his bachelor's degree. His parents had instilled in him what he calls a "do-or-die mindset"‚Äîa philosophy that would prove prophetic.

 

"My father taught me that success isn't just about personal achievement," Nagesh reflects. "It's about lifting your family and extended family along with you. Living simply, staying cheerful, standing by our people‚Äîthese weren't just values, they were survival strategies.‚Äù Those early years built something invaluable: resilience. Little did he know that this small-town foundation would eventually support a career spanning continents and transforming global enterprises.

Starting as a sales trainee, Nagesh eventually found himself at YASH Technologies, working with traditional SAP HCM presales teams and constantly hitting walls. During one particularly frustrating project estimations discussions, a senior consultant delivered advice that would change everything: "If you really want to shape the future, learn SAP‚Äîit's where the biggest challenges and opportunities are."

But it was SAP's acquisition of SuccessFactors that created Nagesh's true "lightbulb moment." While others saw a complex transition, he saw infinite possibility. What happened next was nothing short of extraordinary.

SAP Learning Hub became Nagesh's compass‚Äîhis "go-to resource for quickly building knowledge and completing prerequisites." The comprehensive training, hands-on exercises, and certification preparation materials became the foundation of his transformation. The breakthrough came during a late-night session in his Amsterdam home office. He was trying to build a complex report. Hours of trial and error had left him exhausted and frustrated. Then, using the detailed training materials and practical examples from SAP Learning Hub, it clicked. "I sat there thinking, 'I can build anything with this.' The rush was incredible‚Äù, he remembers.

Here's where Nagesh's story takes a surprising turn. He expected SAP learning to be purely technical‚Äîa skills upgrade to advance his career. Instead, it transformed something he never anticipated: his ability to think like a business leader. The intensive learning journey wouldn't have been possible without key support. Nagesh credits his wife as his anchor, whose unwavering support at home enabled his relentless pursuit of learning without interruption and his mentors across his journey.

Colleagues began noticing that Nagesh brought both big-picture strategy and hands-on expertise to projects. He wasn't just solving technical problems; he was solving business problems.

As Nagesh accumulated SAP Certifications‚Äî through rigorous study with SAP Learning Hub‚Äîeach one became what he calls "another layer of armor."

"Every SAP Certification reinforced my ability not only to tackle complex projects but also to lead others through them," he shares. "They weren't just credentials‚Äîthey were confidence multipliers."

The SAP Certifications opened doors to high-impact global assignments and helped him earn client trust more quickly. But the real transformation was internal: from a small-town graduate to a leader who could walk into any boardroom with complete confidence.

Then came the career-defining moment that validated years of relentless learning. A global client was facing a high-stakes SAP SuccessFactors implementation with a brutal deadline. Their previous attempts had failed. The pressure was immense. Nagesh delivered.

"When their CHRO told me that our solution had transformed how they manage talent worldwide, all those years of learning‚Äîincluding those movie theater study sessions‚Äîsuddenly made perfect sense," he recalls. Today, Nagesh's learning journey continues to impact others in unexpected ways. He's mentored colleagues through their first SAP Certifications, elevated his entire team's capabilities, and regularly shares insights through blogs that help the wider SAP community.

 "My learning journey has been consistent, persistent, and purpose-driven," he notes. "It should be as natural as checking your messages or having your morning coffee."

When asked what movie would capture his learning journey, Nagesh's answer is immediate: "Gully Boy‚ÄîApna time aayega" (Our time will come). It perfectly captures his philosophy: that with persistent learning and unwavering commitment, anyone from anywhere can rise to extraordinary heights. From a movie theater in Amsterdam to global boardrooms, from a small coastal town to becoming a trusted advisor to multinational corporations, Nagesh's story proves a simple truth: learning isn't just about acquiring skills‚Äîit's about transforming your entire life.

Ready to start your own transformation? Benefit from tailored and self-paced learning opportunities that meet you when and where you learn best on the SAP Learning site. Get certified to demonstrate your expertise and boost your career.
